subject: Re: ClassLoader constraints violation
msgSnippet: Thanks Guys, I went with John s -noloading switch, since it seemed quicker and easier and I tend to restart the TestRunner for each execution - it worked fine.
messageBody:
Thanks Guys,

I went with John's -noloading switch, since it seemed quicker and
easier and I tend to restart the TestRunner for each execution - it
worked fine. I can see Erik's excluded.properties providing a finer-
grained control that might be of use in different circumstances.

Either way, that's two useful nuggets. Thank you both for taking the
trouble,

Rupert
--- In junit@y..., john prince <johnprince@t...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I ran up against this problem as well. After reading the 3.5
release notes (I must really have been desperate!), I worked out that
it goes away if you use the -noloading parameter when running JUnit,
i.e. <package>.TestRunner -noloading package.Class
>
> John
>
> > "Rupert" <rupert@t...> wrote:
> > > Anyone shed any light on this? I can run the associated code
against
> > > java, but not through the TestRunner...
> > >
> > > java.lang.LinkageError: Class org/w3c/dom/Element violates
loader
> > > constraints
> > > at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass0(Native Method)
> > > at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java,
> > > Compiled Code)
> > > at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass
(ClassLoader.java:427)
> > > at junit.runner.TestCaseClassLoader.loadClass
> > > (TestCaseClassLoader.java, Compiled Code)...
> >
> > I recently had a similar problem. I decided that it was a
classloader problem
> > (somewhat obvious I guess) and so I excluded the jar file that
was causing me
> > the problems from the classloader by copying
the "excluded.properties" file
> > from the src folder and putting it in a folder in my classpath.
That solved
> > the problem.
> >
> > (I created a "properties" directory and put its path in my
classpath (before
> > junit.jar), and then created a "junit" dir inside "properties"
and a "runner"
> > dir inside "junit" and put the properties file in there. That's
the only way
> > it will work (AFAIK).)
> >
> >
> > Erik
> >
> >
